facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1596 of 1967 filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1596 of 1967.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated July 5, 1956 of Andhra Pradesh High Court in W.P. No. 468 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 5, 1956 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in W.P. No. 468 of 1965.

facts.text: Appellant passed M.B.B.S. examination of Madras University in 1940.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant who has passed the M.B B.S. examination of the Madras University in 1940 entered the service of the State of Madrason August 14, 1941

facts.text: Appellant entered service of State of Madras on August 14, 1941 as Civil Assistant Surgeon.

anchor.surface_text: in 1940 entered the service of the State of Madrason August 14, 1941 as Civil Assistant Surgeon.

facts.text: On formation of State of Andhra Pradesh, appellant's services allotted to new State.

anchor.surface_text: On the formation of the State of Andhra Pradesh his services were allotted to the new State.

facts.text: In 1961, appellant working as Officer-in-charge of Vijaywada Government Headquarters Hospital.

anchor.surface_text: In 1961 he was working as Officer-in-charge of Vijaywada Government Headquarters Hospital.

facts.text: Government of Andhra Pradesh referred case to Tribunal under Andhra Pradesh Civil Services Disciplinary Proceedings Tribunal Act 1960.

anchor.surface_text: On a reference by the Government of Andhra Pradesh, the Tribunal, under the Andhra Pradesh Civil Services  Disciplinary Proceedings  Tribunal Act 1960

facts.text: Tribunal framed charges against appellant on August 22, 1962 by Shri Umpathy Rao, Chairman.

anchor.surface_text: The charges were framed by him on August 22, 1962. On or about January 7, 1963 the case was transferred

facts.text: Tribunal consisted of two members at material times.

anchor.surface_text: which at all material times, companysisted of two members.

facts.text: Case transferred to Shri Nazimuddin on or about January 7, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: On or about January 7, 1963 the case was transferred to the other member Shri Nazimuddin.

facts.text: Appellant protested that Shri Nazimuddin would be biased.

anchor.surface_text: On the protest of the appellant that the said member would be biased against him the case was withdrawn

facts.text: Case withdrawn from Shri Nazimuddin and continued by Shri K. Umpathy Rao until March 21, 1963, examined witnesses.

anchor.surface_text: the case was withdrawn from him and Shri K. Umpathy Rao companytinued the enquiry until March 21, 1963 and examined certain witnesses.

facts.text: Case transferred to Shri Shankar Pershad on March 21, 1963 who succeeded Shri Nazimuddin.

anchor.surface_text: On the same date the case was transferred to Shri Shankar Pershad who had succeeded Shri Nazimmudin on the latters appointment.

facts.text: Shri Shankar Pershad held inquiry until June 20, 1963 and examined witnesses.

anchor.surface_text: Shri Shanker Pershad held the inquiry until June 20, 1963 and examined a number of witnesses.

facts.text: Shri Shankar Pershad retired in July 1963.

anchor.surface_text: He retired in July 1963.

facts.text: Shri G. Ramaiah Chowdhary succeeded Shri Shankar Pershad and continued enquiry, examined witnesses.

anchor.surface_text: Shri G. Ramaiah Chowdhary who succeeded him companytinued to hold the enquiry and examined some witnesses.

facts.text: Arguments heard on October 26, 1963 after written statement and appellant's witnesses examined.

anchor.surface_text: After the written statement of the appellant had been filed and his witnesses had been examined he heard arguments on October 26, 1963.

facts.text: Shri G. Ramaiah Chowdhary transferred on February 2, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Before he companyld submit a report Shri Chowdhary was transferred on February 2, 1964

facts.text: Shri C. Jaganathacharyulu succeeded Shri Chowdhary and was then Chairman of Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: and was succeeded by Shri C. Jaganathacharyulu who was then the Chairman of the Tribunal.

facts.text: Shri C. Jaganathacharyulu submitted report on July 31, 1964 holding 10 out of 22 charges proved.

anchor.surface_text: He submitted a report on July 31, 1964. He held that out of the 22 charges only 10 had been proved.

facts.text: Notice sent to appellant on September 15, 1964 to show cause why dismissed from service.

anchor.surface_text: On September 15, 1964 a numberice was sent to the appellant by the first respondent herein to show cause why he should number be dismissed

facts.text: First respondent directed penalty of dismissal on September 3, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: On September 3, 1964 the first respondent directed that the penalty of dismissal be imposed on the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant filed writ petition in High Court under Art. 226 challenging dismissal order.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant moved the High Court under Art. 226 of the Constitution challenging the order of dismissal from service.

facts.text: Andhra Pradesh High Court dismissed writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: from a judgment of them Andhra Pradesh High Court dismissing a writ petition filed by the appellant

facts.text: Division Bench of High Court decided on September 7, 1965 that single member report invalid under similar Act.

anchor.surface_text: While the writ petition was pending a decision was given by the Division Bench 1  of the High Court on September- 7, 1965 companystruing identical provisions

facts.text: Amendment made to s.7 of the Act by adding proviso.

anchor.surface_text: but for an amendment which was made in s. 7 of the Act by adding a proviso which may be numbericed.

facts.text: Shri Venkatarao heard arguments on 9th and 10th July 1964.

anchor.surface_text: It was pointed out that under sub-rule 6 of Rule 7 Shri Venkata Rao as member of the Tribunal was companypetent to lawfully deal with the evidence... He proceeded to hear arguments on the 9th and 10th July 1964.

facts.text: Shri Venkatarao never examined any witnesses or took evidence on record.

anchor.surface_text: Now it is quite clear that Shri Venkata Rao never examined any witnesses or took on record any evidence.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that proceedings before Tribunal vitiated, report invalid, dismissal illegal.

anchor.surface_text: The result would be that the order of dismissal based on the report submitted by Shri Venkata Rao must be held to be illegal and void. For the reasons given above the appeal is allowed and the order of the High Court is set aside.

facts.text: Appeal allowed, High Court order set aside.

anchor.surface_text: the appeal is allowed and the order of the High Court is set aside.
under Art. 226 of the Constitution challenging the order of dismissal from service.
under the Andhra Pradesh Civil Services Disciplinary Proceedings Tribunal Act 1960, hereinafter called the Act, framed a number of charges against him.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 5, 1956 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in W.P. No. 468 of 1965.

issues.text: whether the proceedings before the Tribunal were vitiated from beginning to the end

anchor.surface_text: The appellant moved the High Court under Art. 226 of the Constitution challenging the order of dismissal principally on the ground that the proceedings before the Tribunal were vitiated from beginning to the end. While the writ petition was pending a decision was given by the Division Bench 1  of the High Court on September- 7, 1965

issues.text: what the true import and meaning of the proviso to s. 7 is

anchor.surface_text: As Rule 7 6 cannot abrogate the provisions contained in the Act and the provisions of the Act must prevail, we shall have to determine what the true import and meaning of the proviso to s. 7 is. It is abundantly clear that according to the substantive part of s. 7 it is the Tribunal which has to report the findings

issues.text: whether the report of Shri Venkata Rao satisfied the conditions laid down in s. 7 and the proviso thereto

anchor.surface_text: The crucial question, therefore, in the present case is whether the report of Shri Venkata Rao satisfied the conditions laid down in s. 7 and the proviso thereto. It is not in dispute that he had never conducted any part of the enquiry and that he had only heard arguments and then submitted a report giving his findings.

anchor.surface_text: He proceeded to hear arguments on the 9th and 10th July 1964. The hearing of arguments was a part of the enquiry under S. 6 1 . It was not, therefore, necessary that the report must have been made by both members of the Tribunal.

arguments.court_reasoning: Arguments follow completion of enquiry per Rule 7(1)(iii); Shri Venkata Rao took no evidence

arguments.claim: Rule 7(6) cannot abrogate provisions of the Act; Act prevails over rules

anchor.surface_text: As Rule 7 6 cannot abrogate the provisions contained in the Act and the provisions of the Act must prevail, we shall have to determine what the true import and meaning of the proviso to s. 7 is.

arguments.claim: Proviso to S.7 applies only if single member himself held the inquiry under S.6(1)

anchor.surface_text: It is abundantly clear that according to the substantive part of s. 7 it is the Tribunal which has to report the findings to the Government on the conclusion of the enquiry. ... The proviso only enables the report to be submitted by one member alone- if the condition pre-requisite is satisfied, namely, that he has held an inquiry himself

arguments.claim: Shri Venkata Rao did not hold any part of the inquiry; only heard arguments

anchor.surface_text: Now it is quite clear that Shri Venkata Rao never examined any witnesses or took on record any evidence. All that he did was to hear arguments afresh.

arguments.claim: Enquiry does not include hearing arguments or recording findings; ends before arguments per Rule 7(1)(iii)

anchor.surface_text: in our opinion the stage of enquiry is completed before the arguments have to be advanced as is clear from Rule 7 1  iii  which is in the following terms - As the enquiry, oral and documentary evidence shall be first adduced ... After the enquiry is completed, the Government servant charged shall be entitled to advance the necessary arguments

arguments.claim: Proviso inserted to allow single member who held inquiry to report alone, per Objects and Reasons

anchor.surface_text: The proviso was inserted as is clear from the statement of Objects and Reasons contained in the Bill ... the intention was that where a single member held an inquiry under s. 6 1  he alone should report his findings ... Where a single member held an inquiry it might not be appropriate to require the other member

arguments.claim: Agrees with Division Bench that 'enquiry' in Act does not include finding; covers recording evidence etc.

anchor.surface_text: In the judgment of the Andhra Pradesh High Court supra it was laid down that the word enquiry in s. 8 of the Act does not include a finding. The enquiry was stated to cover the hearing of the case i.e. recording evidence, admitting documents ... We entirely concur with this view.

arguments.claim: Report of Shri Venkata Rao does not satisfy S.7 and proviso; dismissal illegal

anchor.surface_text: The crucial question, therefore, in the present case is whether the report of Shri Venkata Rao satisfied the conditions laid down in s. 7 and the proviso thereto. ... The result would be that the order of dismissal based on the report submitted by Shri Venkata Rao must be held to be illegal and void.

holdings.text: The report of Shri Venkata Rao does not satisfy the conditions laid down in s. 7 and the proviso thereto because he never conducted any part of the enquiry and only heard arguments.

anchor.surface_text: The crucial question, therefore, in the present case is whether the report of Shri Venkata Rao satisfied the conditions laid down in s. 7 and the proviso thereto. It is not in dispute that he had never conducted any part of the enquiry and that he had only heard arguments and then submitted a report giving his findings.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Shri Venkata Rao examined no witnesses or evidence; per Rule 7(1)(iii), enquiry completes before arguments; proviso requires single member to hold inquiry himself.

holdings.text: Hearing of arguments is not part of the enquiry under S. 6(1); enquiry stage completes before arguments as per Rule 7(1)(iii).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule 7(1)(iii) sequence: evidence first, then after enquiry completed, arguments; Shri Venkata Rao took no evidence.

holdings.text: Rule 7(6) cannot abrogate or override provisions of the Act; provisions of the Act must prevail over rules.

anchor.surface_text: As Rule 7 6 cannot abrogate the provisions contained in the Act and the provisions of the Act must prevail, we shall have to determine what the true import and meaning of the proviso to s. 7 is.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Subordinate rules cannot override parent statute; harmonious construction requires Act to prevail.

holdings.text: Proviso to s.7 enables single member report only if he himself held the inquiry under S.6(1); his report deemed Tribunal's report if condition satisfied.

anchor.surface_text: It is abundantly clear that according to the substantive part of s. 7 it is the Tribunal which has to report the findings to the Government on the conclusion of the enquiry. ... The proviso only enables the report to be submitted by one member alone- if the condition pre-requisite is satisfied, namely, that he has held an inquiry himself

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of s.7 substantive + proviso; purposive from Objects & Reasons: to allow single inquirer to report alone without other member's input.

holdings.text: The order of dismissal based on Shri Venkata Rao's report is illegal and void.

anchor.surface_text: The result would be that the order of dismissal based on the report submitted by Shri Venkata Rao must be held to be illegal and void.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Report invalid under s.7 as condition not met; dismissal solely based thereon void.

holdings.text: The word 'enquiry' in the Act does not include recording findings; covers recording evidence, admitting documents, completing record.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Concurs with Division Bench; consistent with Rule 7 sequence.

holdings.text: Proceedings before Tribunal not vitiated from beginning to end; only final report invalid.

anchor.surface_text: The crucial question, therefore, in the present case is whether the report of Shri Venkata Rao satisfied the conditions laid down in s. 7 and the proviso thereto.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Earlier stages by multiple members valid; vice only in final reporting not complying with s.7.

precedents.citation: C. K. Doraiswamy Naidu v. The State of Andhra Pradesh L.R. 1967 Andhra pradesh. 904.

anchor.surface_text: C. K. Doraiswamy Naidu v. The State of Andhra Pradesh L.R. 1967 Andhra pradesh. 904. members as the Chairman. Under S. 6 (1) if the Tribunal consists of more than one member an inquiry into a case referred to the Tribunal shall be held by all the members sitting together or by a single member as the Chairman may direct.

precedents.case_name: C. K. Doraiswamy Naidu v. The State of Andhra Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: where one member alone conducted an enquiry and submitted his report that report was invalid and opposed to the provisions of the Act and the decision of the Government on such report would be without jurisdiction; the word 'enquiry' does not include a finding but covers the hearing of the case i.e. recording evidence, admitting documents and generally completing the record upon which a finding would be based
precedents.cited_holding: report by single member of multi-member Tribunal invalid; enquiry excludes arguments and findings

anchor.surface_text: The crucial question, therefore, in the present case is whether the report of Shri Venkata Rao satisfied the conditions laid down in s. 7 and the proviso thereto. It is not in dispute that he had never conducted any part of the enquiry and that he had only heard arguments and then submitted a report giving his findings.
For the reasons given above the appeal is allowed and the order of the High Court is set aside.
